title: Valued to Value Others
teaser: How understanding your value in God's eyes empowers you to help others discover theirs
theme: When we truly understand our value in God's eyes, we become passionate about helping others discover theirs

modules.passage: Be on your guard; stand firm in the faith; be courageous; be strong. Do everything in love.
modules.fullPassage: Be on your guard; stand firm in the faith; be courageous; be strong. Do everything in love.

modules.meaning: unconditional love, selfless love, divine love
modules.rootMeaning: Agape is not a feeling but a decision — the deliberate choice to value another person regardless of their response, merit, or condition. It is the love God demonstrated at the cross: choosing to sacrifice for those who had nothing to offer in return.
modules.usageNote: Paul closes his entire letter to the Corinthians with this word. After 16 chapters of correcting division, immorality, and confusion, his final command is simply: do everything in agape. It is both the motivation and the method of the Christian life.

relatedWords.reference: The verb form — to love with agape. Used in John 3:16: 'For God so loved (agapao) the world.'

modules.definition: unconditional love, selfless love, divine love
modules.usage: Agape is the final word of Paul's letter because it is the final word of the gospel. Everything begins and ends with the choice to love as God loves — valuing others not for what they offer, but for who they are.

modules.body:
Paul's closing commands in 1 Corinthians form a five-fold charge: be on guard, stand firm, be courageous, be strong, do everything in love. These are not five separate instructions — they are one instruction with five dimensions. Standing firm in the faith that God values us requires vigilance, courage, and strength. But the purpose of all that standing is not self-preservation — it is love.

Nick's journey from questioning his worth to proclaiming it worldwide required exactly this: standing firm in faith, even when circumstances suggested otherwise. It takes courage to believe we're valued when the world suggests otherwise. It takes strength to love others when we've been rejected.

But when we stand firm in the faith that God values us, we become unshakeable sources of hope for others who are questioning their worth. The boy who once questioned his value now spends his life helping others discover theirs. This is the natural trajectory of received grace: it flows outward.
modules.keyInsight: Understanding your own value in God's eyes is not the destination — it is the launching pad. Received worth becomes given worth. We are valued so that we can value others.

modules.heading: Standing Firm to Love Outward

modules.body:
Today, Nick Vujicic travels the world with his wife Kanae and their children, speaking to millions about their worth in God's eyes. The boy who once questioned his value now spends his life helping others discover theirs. He hugs people with his shoulders, signs autographs with his mouth, and demonstrates that value isn't about what you can do — it's about who you are in Christ.

His Life Without Limbs ministry reaches the hopeless, the broken, and the questioning, offering them the same truth that transformed his despair into purpose: you are valued beyond measure by the God who created you. Nick's simple acts — drinking water, laughing, weeping with those who weep — have all become declarations of God's love to a watching world.
modules.connectionToTheme: Nick's life has come full circle: from questioning whether God valued him to becoming one of the most powerful voices on earth declaring the value of others. Received love always becomes given love.

modules.heading: From Receiver to Giver

modules.body:
The ultimate revelation of our value is this: we have been given the mind of Christ. Paul writes in 1 Corinthians 2:16: 'But we have the mind of Christ.' Nick's transformation came when he began to see himself through Christ's eyes rather than the world's eyes.

With the mind of Christ, we see ourselves as God sees us — beloved, chosen, valuable beyond measure. With the mind of Christ, we see others the same way. Nick's ministry flows from this truth: when we truly understand our value in God's eyes, we become passionate about helping others discover theirs.

When we understand our worth, even the most ordinary activities become acts of worship. Nick's laughter becomes a declaration of God's joy. His tears become evidence of God's compassion. Everything we do becomes an opportunity to reflect His glory to others.
modules.historicalContext: Paul's declaration that believers have 'the mind of Christ' was radical in a culture that reserved divine wisdom for the philosophical elite. In Corinth, knowledge was power, and the educated looked down on the uneducated. Paul insists that every believer — slave or free, educated or not — possesses the very mind of Christ.
modules.fascinatingFact: The phrase 'do everything in love' (1 Corinthians 16:14) uses the Greek word panta — meaning absolutely everything, without exception. Paul is not saying 'do most things in love' or 'do the spiritual things in love.' He means every email, every meal, every conversation, every struggle. For Nick, this means even putting on shoes with his chin is an act of love.

modules.heading: The Mind of Christ

modules.ancientTruth: Paul's final command to the Corinthians was a five-fold charge culminating in love — stand firm so that you can love outward. The entire letter, from division to resurrection, builds toward this single word: agape.
modules.modernApplication: Nick Vujicic's life embodies Paul's charge. He stood firm in faith when his body said he had no value. He was courageous when bullies and despair told him to give up. He was strong when suicide seemed easier. And now he does everything in love — traveling the world to tell others they are valued.
modules.connectionPoint: The trajectory of Nick's life mirrors the trajectory of Paul's letter: from crisis to resolution, from questioning to proclamation, from received grace to given grace. Both end in the same place — love poured outward.
modules.newTestamentEcho: Paul wrote: 'So whether you eat or drink or whatever you do, do it all for the glory of God' (1 Corinthians 10:31). Nick has turned this verse into a daily practice — every act, no matter how small, becomes an offering of glory.

modules.prompt: How would your life change if you truly believed you have the mind of Christ — valued, loved, and purposeful?
additionalQuestions: Where do you need to stand more firmly in your faith about your value to God?
Who in your life needs to hear about their value in God's eyes this week?
What ordinary activity could become an act of worship if you did it with the awareness of your worth?

modules.prayerText: Lord, thank You for this week of discovering our true value in Your eyes. Like Nick, help us move from questioning our worth to proclaiming it. Use our stories — including our limitations — to reveal Your power and love to others. Help me see every action, no matter how small, as an opportunity to bring You glory and show others their value. May we stand firm in the faith that we are valued beyond measure. Amen.

modules.commitment: I will encourage one person today by helping them see their value in God's eyes, and I will live tomorrow as someone who possesses the mind of Christ — valued, loved, and purposeful.
leavingAtCross: The self-focus that makes my worth only about me
The fear of speaking into someone else's life about their value
The belief that understanding my worth is the destination rather than the starting line
receivingFromCross: The mind of Christ — seeing myself and others as God sees us
The courage to stand firm and love outward
The commission to turn received grace into given grace

forReflection: How does having the mind of Christ change how you see yourself and others?
What practical ways can you help others discover their value in God's eyes?
How can you maintain this perspective of value when facing rejection or criticism?
forAccountabilityPartners: Share one person in your life who needs to hear about their value in God's eyes
Identify one way you'll turn your understanding of worth into action this week
Ask each other: 'How can we hold each other accountable to living as valued people who value others?'

modules.name: Nick Vujicic
modules.title: Valued to Value Others
modules.description: Today Nick Vujicic travels the world with his wife Kanae and their four children. He has spoken to over 6 million people in more than 60 countries. The boy who once questioned whether God valued him now devotes his life to helping others discover their worth — hugging people with his shoulders, signing books with his mouth, and proving that value is not about what you can do but about who you are in Christ.
modules.keyQuote: If God can use a man without arms and legs to be His hands and feet, then He will certainly use any willing heart.
modules.lessonForUs: Understanding our value is not the end of the journey — it is the beginning. We are valued so that we can value others. Received grace always becomes given grace.
